text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

RANJAY GULATI: So the
fourth T is tenacity.

And at one level, there
are many close cousins
to the word tenacity.
People have talked about grit.
They've talked about resilience.
What exactly is this?

The point over here is helping
your team build the muscle--

mental muscle-- to really
deal with the highs and lows
of sports.

Sports has winning
and sports has losing,

and so it can be an
emotional roller coaster.

Part of a coach's job is to
keep the players centered.

How do you preserve that sense
of equilibrium on the team?

Now here's the
counterintuitive part.

Don't get so high on the
wins because you're going
to have equally lows on losses.

I talked to Pete
Carroll, actually,

about an infamous moment
in the Super Bowl.

When there's a little
more than two seconds left

in the game and Seattle
has the ball on the 2 yard

line of the New England
Patriots and they're
going to win this game.

Everyone thought
the game was over,
even the New England players.

And instead, what
happens is Russell Wilson
decides to pass the ball--
that was a called play--

instead of running the ball,
and it gets intercepted
and they lose.
And so I asked Pete.

I said, what did you do when you
went back to the locker room?

Because you got
all these players,

and they're calling it on you
saying you called the play.
We lost because of you.

So part of what
happens in losses
is you want someone to blame.

Either it's the coach
or another player
who may have made a mistake.
What did Pete do?

First thing is he
made sure they didn't
blame the players involved.

There were several
players involved

who together should
have not allowed
what happened to happen.
He took it.
He said, I'm the leader.
It's on me.
I called the play.

So deflecting it onto
yourself, avoiding

that blame to set in, helping
people realize and say, look,
let's focus not on winning.

Let's focus on how
well we played.
We had an amazing season.
We have a lot to feel proud of.
Now it's easier said than done.

This is really, really
hard, but winning coaches

say we're building mental
muscle for the long haul.

Nick Saban has a 24-hour rule
where they win the National

championships, and he's
back at work the next day

saying time to plan
for next season.

What did we learn
from last season?

And they're like, come on, we
need to celebrate some more.
It's like, no, onward.

So how to build
that mental muscle.

If you really want to
understand tenacity,

one place to look at it is the
legendary Michael Jordan Nike
advertisement where--
what does Michael Jordan say?

He said, I have missed
9,000 shots over my career.
I've lost almost 300 games.

And 26 times, I was entrusted
to make the game-winning shot,
and I missed.

I have failed over and
over again in my life.
And that is why I succeed.
Keeping that focus.

Yes, I have lost,
but I have succeeded.

We got to give Phil
Jackson credit over here

to really helping his players
put the game in perspective.

By putting it in
perspective doesn't

mean becoming
indifferent to the game.

You want to win, so
don't get me wrong.

It's easy to take this
and say, oh, he was just
saying come on and chill.

No, it's not about
come and have fun.

It was about saying come
and have fun in a way

where you are at
your very best self.

The competition
is not out there.
The competition is you.
And Jordan said that, too.

I'm not here to compete
with anybody else.

I'm here to compete with the
best possible self I can be.

We are in extremely
tumultuous times.
We have a pandemic.

We have a war,
economic uncertainty,

technological uncertainty,
regulatory uncertainty,
supply chain uncertainty.
I can go on and on.

In these tumultuous
times, how do we

hold that collective
tenacity for our team?

You might think that tenacity
is all about coping with losing.
That's what people think.

I've come to realize
tenacity is about also

about coping with winning
because what happens to winning

teams sometimes, and there's
Nobel Prize winning research

on loss avoidance,
is when you've won,

you start to play not to lose
instead of playing to win.

You're so fearful of
losing because you

have this reputation and
you're the National champions.

That's why you see very
few back-to-back national
champions.

Winning organizations
get complacent.
They get arrogant.
They get indifferent.
They get lazy.
They ignore their customers.
They become internally focused.

They become siloed, and
bureaucratic, and slow,
and risk averse.

And a leader's job is to
maintain focus on winning.

Tenacity is as
much about keeping

people's mental
equilibrium after winning
as much as it is after losing.

How do we have that
forward-looking mindset

in the face of ups and downs
that are natural part of life?
[MUSIC PLAYING]
